facts.text: Appeal from the High Court of Judicature at Bombay Civil Appeal No. XII of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: APPEAL from the High Court of Judicature at Bombay Civil Appeal No. XII of 1950. This was an appeal from a judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay  Chagla, Acting C.J. and Bhagwati J.  dated 2nd September, 1947, in Appeal No. 60 of 1946.

facts.text: Judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay by Chagla Acting C.J. and Bhagwati J. dated 2nd September 1947 in Appeal No. 60 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: This was an appeal from a judgment and order of the High Court of Bombay  Chagla, Acting C.J. and Bhagwati J.  dated 2nd September, 1947, in Appeal No. 60 of 1946. The facts are fully set out in the judgment. K. Daphtary, Advocate-General of Bombay  M. M. Desai. with him  for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by KANIA C.J. on 1950 May 27.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. May 27. The judgment of the Court was delivered by KANIA C.J.--This is an appeal from a judgment of the High Court at Bombay and it relates to the jurisdiction of the Court to direct the Chief Controlling Revenue Authority and the Superintendent of Stamps at Bombay to state a case for the opinion of the Court under section 57 of the Stamp Act.

facts.text: Respondent company borrowed money from the Central Bank of India Ltd. at Bombay for its business.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companypany, for its business, borrowed money from the Central Bank of India Ltd. at Bombay. In order to secure the loan a document was executed on the 22nd of March, 1945, with a stamp of Rs. 16-8-0, on the footing that it was a, deed of hypothecation without possession of the goods.

facts.text: Document executed on 22nd March 1945 with stamp of Rs. 16-8-0 as deed of hypothecation without possession.

anchor.surface_text: In order to secure the loan a document was executed on the 22nd of March, 1945, with a stamp of Rs. 16-8-0, on the footing that it was a, deed of hypothecation without possession of the goods. When the deed was sent to the Sub-Registrar for registration he impounded the same and sent it to the Stamp Office.

facts.text: Sub-Registrar impounded the document and sent it to the Stamp Office.

anchor.surface_text: When the deed was sent to the Sub-Registrar for registration he impounded the same and sent it to the Stamp Office. The Assistant Superintendent of Stamps wrote to the respondent that the document was a mortgage with possession, chargeable with duty under article 40  a  of the Schedule and inquired why it was number duly stamped before execution.

facts.text: Assistant Superintendent of Stamps stated document was mortgage with possession chargeable under article 40(a).

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Superintendent of Stamps wrote to the respondent that the document was a mortgage with possession, chargeable with duty under article 40  a  of the Schedule and inquired why it was number duly stamped before execution. The respondents solicitors in their reply companytended that the document was number, and was never intended by the parties to be, a mortgage with possession.

facts.text: Respondent's solicitors contended document not mortgage with possession, no possession given or intended except contingencies, properly stamped.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents solicitors in their reply companytended that the document was number, and was never intended by the parties to be, a mortgage with possession. They pointed out that numberpossession of the property had been given or was intended to be given, except in certain companytin- gencies and therefore the document was properly stamped.

facts.text: Assistant Superintendent intimated duty of Rs. 56,250 and penalty of Rs. 5,000 imposed.

anchor.surface_text: In reply the Assistant Superintendent intimated that the docu- ment was chargeable with duty of Rs. 56,250 and a penalty of Rs. 5,000 had been imposed. The respondents were asked to pay the amount forthwith.

facts.text: On 27th July 1945 respondent filed suit against Central Bank contending document not mortgage with possession, seeking rectification if needed.

anchor.surface_text: On the 27th July, 1945, the respondent filed a suit against the Central Bank companytending that the document was number a mortgage with possession. It was alleged that since a doubt had arisen as to whether the document gave effect to the companymon intention of the parties the Courts directions were sought for and if the Court found that the document as framed did number give effect to the said companymon intention of the parties the instrument may be rectified.

facts.text: On 9th August 1945 respondents solicitors informed Assistant Superintendent of suit filed and requested not to press demand.

anchor.surface_text: On 9th August, 1945, the respondents solicitors informed the Assistant Superintendent that such a suit had been filed and requested that the demand for payment of stamp duty and penalty may number be pressed under the circumstances.

facts.text: Demand reiterated and threat of coercive procedure under section 48.

anchor.surface_text: In the further companyrespondence, on behalf of the appellant, the demand was reiterated and resort to the companyrcive procedure of section 48 of the Stamp Act was threatened.

facts.text: Collector sent letter demanding payment on 17th January 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector thereafter sent a letter to the respondents on the 17th January, 1946, demanding payment.

facts.text: On 25th January 1946 suit disposed of by court and rectification ordered.

anchor.surface_text: On the 25th of January, 1946, the suit filed by the respond- ent was disposed of by the Court and the rectification as prayed was ordered.

facts.text: Respondents solicitors intimated result of suit to Assistant Superintendent and sent copy of rectified deed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents solicitors immediately intimated the result of the suit to the Assistant Superin- tendent and sent a companyy of the deed showing the rectifica- tions made in the original document.

facts.text: Similar letter sent to Collector of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: A similar letter was also sent to the Collector of Bombay.

facts.text: On 1st February 1946 respondents solicitors enquired if Assistant Superintendent agreeable to reference under section 56(2).

anchor.surface_text: On the 1st February, 1946, the respondents solictors enquired of the Assistant Superintendent of Stamps whether he was agree- able to make a reference under section 56  2  to the appel- lant, as the question of liability to pay the stamp duty and. penalty involved important questions of law.

facts.text: Petition filed to appellant on 5th February 1946 praying rescind order or refer under section 57.

anchor.surface_text: A petition on behalf of the respondent to the appellant was also filed on the 5th of February in which it was prayed that either the order of the Assistant Superintendent of Stamps be rescinded or in the alternative a case may be referred under section 57 of the Stamp Act for the opinion of the High Court.

facts.text: Petition rejected on 4th July 1946.

anchor.surface_text: This petition was rejected on the 4th July, 1946.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition in High Court on 19th July 1946 for writ of certiorari or order under s.45 Specific Relief Act or order under s.57.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent there- upon filed a petition in the High Court on the 19th of July, 1946, praying that a writ of certiorari may be issued against the appellant, or an order may be made against him under section 45 of the Specific Relief Act, to cancel the levy of the stamp duty and penalty as claimed on behalf of the appellant or in the alter- native the appellant may be ordered under section 57 of the Stamp Act to refer the matter to the High Court for its opinion.

facts.text: Mr. Justice Blagden did not grant first relief but directed appellant to state case under s.57.

anchor.surface_text: The matter came for hearing before Mr. Justice Blagden who did number grant the first relief but directed the appellant to state a case under section 57 of the Stamp Act to the Court for its opinion.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeal in High Court but failed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an appeal but failed. He has number companye in appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Appellant appeals to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: He has number companye in appeal to this Court.

issues.text: whether under section 57 of the Stamp Act there is an obligation on the appellant to state a case, and if not whether the High Court had jurisdiction to give a direction to that effect

anchor.surface_text: under section 57 of the Stamp Act there is an obligation on the appellant to state a case, and if not whether the High Court had jurisdiction to give a direction to that effect.

issues.text: whether having regard to the terms of section 226 (1) of the Government of India Act, 1935, the High Court had jurisdiction to order the appellant to state the case, it being a matter relating to the revenue. Under this head it is also argued that the matter had proceeded beyond the stage of assessment and had reached the stage of recovery. Therefore, the High Court of Bombay had no jurisdiction to pass the order it did.

anchor.surface_text: The second point is whether having regard to the terms of section 226 1 of the Government of India Act, 1935, the High Court had jurisdiction to order the appellant to state the case, it being a matter relating to the revenue. Under this head it is also argued that the matter had proceeded beyond the stage of assessment and,had reached the stage of recovery.

arguments.claim: Section 57 of the Stamp Act gives only a discretionary power to the Chief Controlling Revenue Authority to state a case, not an obligation

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it is contended that the very words of section 57 of the Stamp Act show that it is a power given to the appellant to state a case and it is not an obligation. The section is framed and worded only to give the benefit thereof to the appellant

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Court to send a statement of case to the appellant and the High Court respectively, in our opinion, instead of helping the appellant, go against his c

arguments.court_reasoning: Power is coupled with a duty when important question of law arises; not merely discretionary

arguments.claim: The word 'may' in section 57 was deliberately used to confer benefit only on the authority, not on other parties

anchor.surface_text: and it is not for the benefit of any other party. The word may used in the section was deliberately used for that purpose.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Court to send a statement of case to the appellant and the High Court respectively, in our opinion, instead of helping the appellant, go against his c

arguments.court_reasoning: Power enures to benefit of party affected by assessment

arguments.claim: Section 57 is analogous to sections 56(2) and 60, which confer discretionary power only for the benefit of the referring authority or court

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that under section 56 ( 2 ) of the Stamp Act if the Collector felt doubt as to the amount of duty with which the instrument was chargeable he may draw up a statement of the case and refer it with his opinion for the decision of the Chief Controlling Revenue Authority. Similarly under section 60 if any Court felt doubt as to the amount of duty to be paid it was given power to draw up a statement of case

arguments.claim: Under the Stamp Act, if Collector certifies under s32 even if faulty, Controlling Authority cannot refer for higher duty

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that under the Stamp Act a Collector could certify that the document was properly stamped, although it was not sufficiently stamped on a true construction, and when such a certificate was given the Controlling Authority could do nothing. He had not even the power to refer that case to the Court to levy a higher stamp duty.

The argument was urged in two parts Firstly, that this being a revenue matter, the jurisdiction of the Court was excluded.

arguments.claim: Power under s57 is coupled with a duty to state case when serious question of law arises

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the power contained in section 57 is in the nature of an obligation or is coupled with an obligation and under the circumstances can be demanded to be used also by the parties affected by the assessment of the stamp duty.

arguments.claim: Absence of 'feels doubt' language in s57 distinguishes it from s56(2) and s60, benefiting affected party

anchor.surface_text: The absence of the words feels doubt as to the amount of duty to be paid in respect of an instrument in section 57 supports the view that the reference contemplated under that section is not for the benefit of the appellant only but enures also for the benefit of the party affected by the assessment.

arguments.claim: Follows Alcock Ashdown case and Julius v Bishop: power coupled with duty

anchor.surface_text: To use the language of Lord Cairns in the case of Julius v. Bishop of Oxford ... which may couple the power with a duty, and make it the duty of the person in whom the power is reposed to exercise that power when called upon to do so.

arguments.claim: High Court order to state case is not original jurisdiction in revenue under s226(1) GOI Act

anchor.surface_text: In their Lordships view the order of a High Court to a revenue officer to do his statutory duty would not be the exercise of original jurisdiction in any matter concerning the revenue.

arguments.claim: Document was not a mortgage with possession; no possession intended except contingencies; properly stamped

It was alleged that since a doubt had arisen as to whether the document gave effect to the common intention of the parties the Courts directions were sought

holdings.text: The power contained in section 57 is in the nature of an obligation or is coupled with an obligation and under the circumstances can be demanded to be used also by the parties affected by the assessment of the stamp duty.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the power contained in section 57 is in the nature of an obligation or is coupled with an obliga- tion and under the circumstances can be demanded to be used also by the parties affected by the assessment of the stamp

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of 'feels doubt' distinguishes from ss56(2),60; power benefits affected party; follows Julius v Bishop (power coupled with duty based on nature/object/conditions) and Alcock Ashdown (similar IT provision imposes duty unless frivolous).

holdings.text: If he omits to do so it is within the power of the Court to direct him to discharge that duty and make a reference to the Court.

anchor.surface_text: If he omits to do so it is within the power of the Court to direct him to discharge that duty and make a reference to the Court. Mr. Daphtary on behalf of the appellant tried to distin- guish this case on the ground that the scheme of the Income

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authority's duty as public officer; court controls refusal when serious law point; principles from Alcock apply despite scheme differences.

holdings.text: In their Lordships view the order of a High Court to a revenue officer to do his statutory duty would not be the exercise of original jurisdiction in any matter concerning the revenue.

anchor.surface_text: In their Lordships view the order of a High Court to a revenue officer to do his statutory duty would not be the exercise of original jurisdiction in any matter concerning the revenue. In our opinion, in the present case also, the respondent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compelling statutory duty not 'original jurisdiction in revenue matter'; follows Alcock rejecting similar bar under GOI Act 1915 s106(2).

holdings.text: The further argument that the proceedings in this case had passed beyond the stage of assessment and had reached the stage of enforcing payment is again irrelevant because by the relief granted by the High Court no attempt is made to obstruct the Revenue Authority in the discharge of his duties.

anchor.surface_text: The further argument that the proceedings in this case had passed beyond the stage of assessment and had reached the stage of collection of stamp duty. On that ground the present case was sought to be distinguished from Alcocks case

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relief only directs reference, does not obstruct recovery duties.

precedents.citation: Alcock, Ashdown Co. Ltd. v. Chief Revenue Authority, Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: Alcock, Ashdown Co. Ltd. v. Chief Revenue Authority, Bombay 1 . In that case a question arose about an asses- sees right to ask the Commissioner of Income Tax to state a case for the opinion of the Court under section 51 of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1918.

precedents.case_name: Alcock Ashdown & Co Ltd v Chief Revenue Authority Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Chief Revenue Authority has duty to state case for High Court opinion on serious question of law under Income Tax Act, and High Court can direct it despite revenue exclusion provisions
precedents.cited_holding: if the assessee applies for a case the Authority must state it unless frivolous or unnecessary; power coupled with duty; High Court order to perform statutory duty not original jurisdiction concerning revenue

anchor.surface_text: the principle being exemplified in the case of Spooner v. Juddow 1   and upon section 106 2 of the Government of India Act, 1915. The judgment of the Board companysisting of Viscount Haldane, Lord Phillimore and Lord Carson was delivered by Lord Phillimore.

precedents.cited_proposition: exclusion of revenue matters from consideration of ordinary civil courts

anchor.surface_text: To use the language of Lord Cairns in the case of Julius v. Bishop of Oxford 1  There may be something in the nature of the thing empowered to be done, something in the object for which it is to be done, something in the companyditions under which it is to be done, something in the title of the person or persons for whose bene- fit the power is to be exercised, which may companyple the power with a duty, and make it the duty of the person in whom the power is reposed to exercise that power when called upon to do so.

precedents.cited_proposition: power given to public authority may be coupled with duty to exercise it in certain circumstances
precedents.cited_holding: There may be something in the nature of the thing empowered to be done... which may couple the power with a duty

anchor.surface_text: On that point their Lordships observed as follows -- Upon the point thus broadly stated their Lordships have numberdifficulty in pronouncing a decision. To argue that if the legislature says that a public officer, even a revenue officer, shall do a thing and he, without cause or justifi- cation, refused to ,do that thing, yet the Specific Relief Act would number be applicable and there would be numberpower in the Court to companypel him to give relief to the subject is to state a  1  50 I.A. 227. proposition to which their Lordships must refuse assent.

precedents.case_name: Alcock Ashdown & Co Ltd v Chief Revenue Authority Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court jurisdiction to order revenue authority to perform statutory duty not barred by revenue exclusion

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the argument that because of section 106 2 of the Government of India Act, 1915, the High Court had numberjurisdiction to make the order, the Board observed as fol- lows -- In their Lordships view the order of a High Court to a revenue officer to do his statutory duty would number be the exercise of original jurisdiction in any matter companycern- ing the revenue. In our opinion, in the present case also, the respondent seeks the Courts intervention to make the appellant perform his statutory duty to state a case. That is number exercising the original jurisdiction of the Court in any matter companycerning the revenue.  1  50 I.A. 227.

precedents.case_name: Alcock Ashdown & Co Ltd v Chief Revenue Authority Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: order to revenue officer to do statutory duty not exercise of original jurisdiction concerning revenue
